title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
In this module, we will cover full structural equation modeling (SEM) and take a deep dive into mediation analysis as a motivating application of SEM.
Lecture Slides

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
Videos

Full SEM



Mediation Basics



Mediation Testing



Bootstrapping



Parallel Multiple Mediator Models
Note: In the following recording, I misspoke when discussing the bias-corrected and accelerated confidence interval (BCa CI) on Slide 75. While the BCa CI does, indeed, correct for bias and skewness in the empirical sampling distribution, the CI calculated by lavaan::parameterEstimates() when specifying boot.ci.type = “bca.simple” does not include the acceleration correction. So, the intervals we get from lavaan are only corrected for bias in the empirical sampling distribution. For more (technical) information about the different flavors of bootstrapped CI, see DiCiccio & Efron (1996).



Serial Multiple Mediator Models



Model Modification & Pruning



Bigger Models



Mediation with Latent Variables

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
To kick things off in style, we have a special treat: a video lecture from the author of lavaan, himself, Yves Rosseel. In the following video, Yves gives you the developer’s perspective on the motivation for, and history of, the lavaan project. In addition to an interesting discussion of lavaan’s development history, you will also get to “peak behind the curtain” as Yves discusses some of the more negative aspects of developing open-source software. Enjoy this candid look into the mind of lavaan’s creator, and feel free to leave your thoughts in the comments section below.

Lecture Slides

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
The page linked below demonstrates how to estimate several different flavors of the RI-CLPM in lavaan.

https://jeroendmulder.github.io/RI-CLPM/lavaan.html

On the two pages linked below, the GORICA is applied to an RI-CLPM (here, to evaluate causal dominance hypotheses where strengths of cross-lagged effects are compared).

https://jeroendmulder.github.io/RI-CLPM/lavaan.html#gorica
https://github.com/rebeccakuiper/Tutorials/tree/main/GORICA%20in%20RI-CLPM

A reference for the RI-CLPM:
Hamaker, E. L., Kuiper, R. M., & Grasman, R. P. P. P. (2015). A critique of the cross-lagged panel model. Psychological Methods, 20(1), 102–116. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0038889

Link to preprint

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
The following papers discuss network models and DAGS:
Bringmann LF, Vissers N, Wichers M, Geschwind N, Kuppens P, Peeters F, et al. (2013). A Network Approach to Psychopathology: New Insights into Clinical Longitudinal Data. PLoS ONE 8(4): e60188. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0060188

Correction: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0096588

Ryan, O., Bringmann, L. F., & Schuurman, N. K. (2022). The Challenge of Generating Causal Hypotheses Using Network Models. Structural Equation Modeling: A Multidisciplinary Journal, 29(6), 953–970. https://doi.org/10.1080/10705511.2022.2056039

Link to preprint

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
Welcome to the last lecture of this course. This lecture gives you an introduction to model selection for lavaan SEM models, where we will mainly look at the AIC and the so-called GORICA and at IC weights.
You can dowload the slides of this lecture below. I also added a new set of slides that contain the newest R code (of the R package restriktor).
Lecture Slides from Recording   Updated Lecture Slides
Note: If, after the course, you want to use GORIC or GORICA in your own research, feel free to contact me.

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
Welcome to the first lecture of this course. This lecture gives you an introduction to SEM in lavaan and, more specifically, to running a regression model using lavaan.
You can download the (updated) slides of this lecture below. Please note the change on the slide “4. Specify your model: regression answer 2”.
Lecture Slides

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
These resources can help you get up-to-speed with basic R usage.

For a book-length treatment, I like R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham and friends.
This link leads to a quick-and-dirty, interactive tutorial that I frequently use to help students prep for R-heavy courses at UU.
The Posit Recipes page contains many helpful tutorials and R code snippets that demonstrate what the Posit/RStudio team views as best practices in R programming.
The R-Primers project created by Andrew Heiss provides a pretty comprehensive series of interactive tutorials covering basic R programming. These tutorials were originally hosted by the Posit/RStudio team, but the Posit-hosted versions are no longer available. So, Heiss did us all a huge favor and ported the Posit Primer materials to an independent, WebR-based project.

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
In this module, we will go over moderation analysis using lavaan, including how to specify interactions between latent variables and how to use multiple group models to test for moderation by group.
Lecture Slides

title: Structural Equation Modeling in R using Lavaan
text:
In this module, we’ll cover methods for analyzing incomplete data using lavaan. We’ll cover both imputation-based solutions and ML-based solutions to the missing data problem.
